unnormalised: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) released new data today revealing a significant increase in spending on international travel by Indian tourists. During the quarter ending June 30th, 2024, Indians spent approximately ₹2.5 lakh crore on foreign trips. This represents a 25% increase compared to the same period last year, where total expenditure was ₹2 lakh crore. Experts attribute this surge to the rising disposable incomes of the middle class and the increasing availability of affordable travel packages.
normalised: The Reserve Bank of India (R-B-I) released new data today revealing a significant increase in spending on international travel by Indian tourists. During the quarter ending June thirtieth, two thousand and twenty four, Indians spent approximately rupee two point five lakh crore on foreign trips. This represents a twenty five percent increase compared to the same period last year, where total expenditure was rupee two lakh crore. Experts attribute this surge to the rising disposable incomes of the middle class and the increasing availability of affordable travel packages.

unnormalised: Breakdown of spending showed a large portion went towards accommodation, with an average of $150 per night spent on hotels. Airfare costs also played a significant role, with round-trip tickets averaging ₹35,000. Popular destinations like Thailand, Singapore, and Dubai accounted for a substantial share of the expenditure. A concerning trend, however, is the increased use of credit cards for travel-related expenses. Many individuals are now finding themselves with high credit card bills of ₹50,000+ post their vacations.
